text:
In southwestern China,
engineers are putting

the finishing touches on
a grand astronomy facility:

A half-kilometer wide dish
nestled in themountains

that will gather radio
signals from the cosmos.

FAST -- set to be the world’s largest radio
telescope-

is modeled on the second
largest dish in the world,
the Arecibo Observatory

Started in 2011, the cost of
construction for the FAST facility

is estimated to be
$180 million dollars.

Spherical dishes reflect and
concentrate incoming waves

from a range of angles,
but not onto a single point,

delivering a distorted
image to receivers.
FAST is breaking new ground with a design

that pulls a section of the dish
into a gradually moving parabola

An array of actuators pull a 300-meter section
into a temporary shape --

this can be aimed at and track
cosmic objects as the Earth rotates

The receiver moves in concert
with the axis of the parabola

This brings the benefits of
a rotating, tilting antenna
to a dish that is firmly fixed in place.

Single dishes excel at
observing point sources

like neutron stars and
at scanning a multitude

of frequencies in the search
for extraterrestrial intelligence

When it comes online, the world’s largest
radio telescope will also catalog pulsars,

as well as probe gravitational
waves, dark matter,

and a recently discovered
phenomenon called fast-radio bursts
